body: putting this on the benchmarking workstream since thatÂ´s what the benchmark data sets are going to be in (probably?)

issue.title: [BUG] Fix `write_ndarray_to_tsfile` for `classLabel = False`

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes the following issue when reading a tsfile written with `write_ndarray_to_tsfile`

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OSError                                   Traceback (most recent call last)
/tmp/ipykernel_1092/2889448795.py in <module>
----> 1 df = load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe("./amex_train_1.ts/AMEX-Data/AMEX-Data.ts", replace_missing_vals_with='NaN', return_separate_X_and_y=False)

/tmp/ipykernel_1092/3989994789.py in load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe(full_file_path_and_name, return_separate_X_and_y, replace_missing_vals_with)
    159                         print(has_data_tag)
    160                         raise IOError(
--> 161                             "a full set of metadata has not been provided "
    162                             "before the data"
    163                         )

OSError: a full set of metadata has not been provided before the data
```


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
The issue in `load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe` happend because `has_class_labels_tag = False`. This is because the line 

```python
elif line.startswith("@classlabel"):
     ....
     has_class_labels_tag = True
```
is never  executed since the `line.startswith("@classlabel")` is `False`

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

How should the tag "@classlabel" be named,  `write_ndarray_to_tsfile` and `load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe` depend on each other here. Another solution would be to allow multiple way of writing this tag in `load_from_tsfile_to_dataframe`


##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

body:
FYI @paulbauriegel, @achieveordie, @TNTran92.

Related discussion: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3303
write/load were inconsistent since they seemed to assume minimally different format specificaitons (identifier strings).

I think we should document the file format properly.

@paulbauriegel, @achieveordie, you looked recently into loaders/writers, so you are probably the resident experts on the ts, tsf file formats? The original authors have disengaged, unfortunately.

The output could be a formal rst page in the docs - or a markdown, if rst is too much of a hassle. We can convert it to "nice" doc format later, I feel it would be key to have the format written down somewhere or we will keep discovering bugs like #3303 ...

It should be noted that the current implementation supports both `@classlabel` and `@classLabel` due to 

```python
line = line.strip().lower()
```

in `_read_header` (line 247) in `sktime/datasets/_data_io.py`. 

As @fkiraly mentioned there is no common standard for instance most datasets from [tseregression.org](http://tseregression.org/) like `AppliancesEnergy` uses all lowercase notation. 
And most classification datasets from [www.timeseriesclassification.com](http://www.timeseriesclassification.com/index.php) like `ArrowHead`  use the CamelCase notation. The `UnitTest` dataset for this module does also use CamelCase.

I think this is because all the classification datasets where made for this code initially: https://github.com/uea-machine-learning/tsml/blob/master/src/main/java/experiments/data/TSReader.java

And the regression datasets where made for this library initially: https://github.com/ChangWeiTan/TS-Extrinsic-Regression/blob/master/utils/data_loader.py

I checked all datasets from here: [Regression](https://zenodo.org/record/3902651) & [Classification](http://www.timeseriesclassification.com/dataset.php). I don't understand the specification completely but this is what I got so far:

### Specification for Regression datasets

|metadata name |data type|comment|
|--------------|----------|----------|
|`@problemname`|`string`     |Name of the data-set|
|`@timestamps`|`false`/`true`|Contains a time-series column|
|`@missing`|`false`/`true`|Contains missing values|
|`@univariate`|`false`/`true`|One variable data-set|
|`@dimension`|`integer`|Only if `univariate=false`, specifies the number of variables |
|`@equallength`|`false`/`true`|All observations have the same number of timestamps |
|`@serieslength`|`integer`|Only if `equallength=true`, specifies the number of timestamps |
|`@targetlabel`|`false`/`true`| Has a target label |


### Specification for Classification datasets

|metadata name |data type|comment|
|--------------|----------|----------|
|`@problemName`|`string`     |Name of the data-set|
|`@timeStamps`|`false`/`true`|I've only seen it false in all the classification datasets|
|`@missing`|`false`/`true`|Contains missing values, I've only seen it false in all the classification datasets|
|`@univariate`|`false`/`true`|One variable data-set|
|`@dimensions`|`integer`|Only if `univariate=false`, specifies the number of variables |
|`@equalLength`|`false`/`true`|All observations have the same number of timestamps |
|`@seriesLength`|`integer`|Only if `equallength=true`, specifies the number of timestamps |
|`@classLabel`|`false`/`true` - **if classLabel=true* `list[string, space seperated]`  | Has/Hasn't a class column - if yes specification of possible class label values (list of space separated strings) |

### Key differences in the datasets
- `dimension` vs `dimensions`
- `targetlabel` vs `classLabel`
- `lowercase` vs `camelCase`
- `@data` field is structured differently

@paulbauriegel, very helpful!

Looks like we will have to work with aliases here, to agree with all existing data files - apparently they have been handled inconsistently

> `@data` field is structured differently

How is the `@data` field structured?

Other questions:
Can the data format currently store:

* the time index for a collection of time series of different length, or with different index set?
* a single time series (in constrast to a collection with 1 instance)
* a hierarchical index

?

Will try to answer those questions in detail as soon as I get to it. Linking existing documentation on the topic here for now:
- https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/examples/loading_data.ipynb
- https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/examples/AA_datatypes_and_datasets.ipynb

issue.title: [ENH] Add File Format Specification for `.ts` and `.tsf`

repository.name: sktime

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Fixes #2043

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Adding a reStructuredText file that will enable users to create their own `.ts` files, given a dataset. 
This document intends to:
- Introduce the idea of string identifiers and why are they required.
- Give an overview of different string identifiers present.
- Present a concise set of instructions for adding these identifiers in the dataset.  

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->

- [x] Add introduction
- [x] Create an overview
- [x] Provide Instructions

Possible changes:
- [x] Restructure the overview table
- [ ] Add missing string identifiers 

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [MNT], [DOC], or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, maintenance, documentation, or bug.

<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
